questions.text: What is meant by the term sociology?

choices.text: Study of developments in the society
Study of formation of social organisations and government
Study of human relationships and behavior
Study of social and cultural history of man

questions.solution: Sociology is considered to be both the study of human relationships and of human behavior.

questions.text: Which of the following social sciences does not deal directly with human behavior?
questions.solution:
Political science refers to the study of the judicial systems and institutions that constitute the government. It does not deal directly with human behavior.

Anthropology is the study of the physical, social, and cultural history of man. Social anthropology is extensively used in preventive and social medicine.

Social psychology is aimed at understanding the basis of perception, thoughts, ideas, etc., among people in a society or group.

Sociology is the study of human relationships and human behavior.

questions.text:
Match the following:
Social Sciences Definition
1.     Social pathology i. Study of social factors influencing human disease
2.    Social medicine ii. The provision of medical service by State, operated and regulated by professional groups
3.   Socialized medicine iii. Effect of social environment on people and their attitude
4.    Social psychology iv. Promotion of methods for prevention of disease and health measures
questions.solution:
Social pathology refers to the study of social factors, which influence human disease and incite social disorganization. This includes crime, poverty, delinquency, abuse, etc.

Social medicine is an organized investigation of the social, environmental, and genetic factors affecting disease patterns and disability. It also deals with the promotion of methods for the prevention of disease and health measures.

Socialized medicine is the provision of medical service and education by the State. It is operated and regulated by professional groups, and not the government.

Social psychology is the effect of the social environment on people, their attitudes, and motivation. It deals with the study of human behavior, thoughts, and feelings and how they are influenced by the perception of others in society.

questions.text: 'Putting profit ahead of health' as a cause of disease belongs to which theory of sociology of health?
questions.solution:
Putting profit ahead of health is termed as the cause of disease in the Marxist theory of sociology of health.

Elias' theory focused on the relationship between power, behavior, emotion, and knowledge over time.

Theory Marxist Parsonian Foucauldian

To discipline and control the working class 

To provide individualized explanations of the disease

Rehabilitate individuals to carry out their social roles

To enforce compliance with the normal social roles and to ensure internalization of these norms.

questions.text: Which of the following refers to a system of social relationships between individuals?
questions.solution:
Society is the system of social relationships between people in an area.

A community is a social group determined by geographical boundaries and/or common values and interests.

A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.

Social Institutions are organized complex patterns of behavior in which a number of people engage to further a common interest.

questions.text: Which of the following options is correctly matched?

choices.text: Social institution- the pattern of inter-relations between persons in a society
Socialism- organised complex patterns of behaviour in people with a common interest
Social structure- system of governance based on social ownership
Socialization- the process by which a person imbibes the social beliefs and customes

questions.solution:
Socialization is the process by which a person in a society imbibes its beliefs, customs, etc. through daily interaction with its members.

Social institutions are organized complex patterns of behaviour in which a number of people engage to further a common interest. Examples are families, schools, hospitals, etc.

Socialism is a system of governance in which production and distribution is based on social ownership (and not private ownership). It is aimed at improving the living standard.

Social structure is the pattern of inter-relations between persons in a society.

questions.text: Which of the following terms is used to describe the preventive, therapeutic, and rehabilitative services for the protection of society from antisocial, criminal, or deviant conduct of man?
questions.solution:
Preventive, therapeutic and rehabilitative services for the protection of society from antisocial, criminal or deviant conduct of man is known as social defence.

This is in the form of acts, laws and judicial instructions for elements like juvenile delinquency, begging, prison reforms, gambling, etc.

questions.text:
Match the following.
Terms Definitions
1. Customs i. Scale of the expenditure of a society, the goods, and services
2. Standard of living  ii. Duties assumed by a person of a particular society
3. Culture iii. Learned behavior which is socially acquired
4. Role iv. Traditionally accepted ways of behaving in a society
questions.solution:
Culture is the socially acquired learned behaviour. It is passed onto generations through formal and informal learning. It is the representation of customs, beliefs, laws, arts, and moral values of a society. Cultural factors have a large part to play in health.

Customs are the traditionally accepted ways of behaving that is specific to a society. They can be folkways, which are referred to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct. Mores are stringent customs followed by a society.

Standard of living refers to the scale of the expenditure of a society, the goods they consume and the services they enjoy.

Role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

questions.text: Which of the following does not bring about acculturation?
questions.solution:
Acculturation is the process by which there is the diffusion of cultures between two culturally different groups of people. Acculturation does not take place by folklore. Folklore is the passage of customs and beliefs of a community through generations, merely by word of mouth.

Acculturation can happen in the following ways:

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Religious propagation
  • Education
  • Conquest

This phenomenon is also known as culture contact.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct ascending order of the Maslow’s hierarchy of needs?
questions.solution:
Maslow’s hierarchy of needs was suggested by psychologist Abraham Maslow. It is a motivational theory in psychology where human needs are arranged according to hierarchy in a five-level pyramid.

He suggested that the higher needs can be fulfilled only once the lower needs are fulfilled.

questions.text: Which of the following could be classified as an ego-integrative need of man?
questions.solution:
Ego-integrative needs of man include power, prestige and self-respect.

The needs of man are as follows:

  • Biological needs- water, food, warmth, medicines, etc.
  • Social needs- love and affection, fellowship, education, etc.
  • Economic needs- money and security
  • Ego-integrative needs- power, prestige and self-respect.

questions.text: What is the benefit that comes from solving one’s own problems termed?
questions.solution:
Intrinsic incentives are the benefits that come from solving one’s own problems.

Incentives are entities that motivate or encourage a specific behaviour. They are generally positive motivators. The various types of incentives are:

  • Intrinsic incentives are the benefits that come from solving one’s own problems.
  • Extrinsic incentives are rewards that do not relate directly to the goal of the desired behaviour like financial compensation for sterilization.
  • Psychological incentives include satisfaction, increased self-esteem, etc.
  • Material incentives include goods or services or financial compensation.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about attitudes in human behaviour?

choices.text: It is acquired from social interactions
It includes an affective or feeling element
It pre-disposes one to respond in a preferential manner
It is a temporary and fleeting aspect of human behaviour

questions.solution:
Attitude is usually a permanent aspect of a human’s behaviour and is difficult to change.

It is the enduring organization of beliefs around something that pre-disposes one to respond in a preferential manner. It is usually acquired through social interactions.

Attitude includes three components:

  • A cognitive or knowledge element
  • An affective or feeling element
  • A tendency to act

questions.text: Which of the following terms represent the temporary and provisional views held by people at a point of dispute?
questions.solution:
Opinions are temporary and provisional views held by people at a point of dispute.

Beliefs are permanent and stable inner subjective thoughts of a person towards things that are without proof. These are usually acquired from family and other close contacts.

questions.text:
Match the following types of learning:
1. Cognitive learning A. Skills
2. Affective learning B. Knowledge
3. Psychomotor learning C. Attitudes
questions.solution:
Learning is any relative or permanent change in behaviour as a result of practice or experience. It includes acquiring knowledge and skills, formation of habits and development of perception.

Types of learning:

  • Cognitive learning – knowledge
  • Affective learning – attitudes
  • Psychomotor learning – skills

The conditions that affect learning are as follows:

  • Intelligence
  • Age
  • Learning situation
  • Motivation
  • Physical and mental health

Theories of learning:

  • Learning by conditioned reflex
  • Trial and error
  • Learning by observation and imitation
  • Learning by doing
  • Learning by remembering
  • Learning by insight
  • Demonstration
  • Field experience
  • Problem solving

questions.text: A 6-yr-old boy is brought to the clinical psychologist for evaluation of intellectual disability. Which formula will she use to calculate the IQ of the child?
questions.solution:
The intelligence quotient is a score that is obtained from several standardized tests to assess human intelligence.

Intelligence quotient (IQ) = Mental age x 100 / Chronological age

questions.text: Which of the following is an important epidemiological tool to assess disability in children?

choices.text: Wing’s Comprehensive Handicaps, Behaviour and Skills Schedule

questions.solution:
Wing’s Comprehensive Handicaps, Behaviour and Skills Schedule (HBS) has been used in epidemiological studies to assess the total child population in terms of detailed scales of specific abilities and disabilities.

HBS is not useful for children with mental retardation.
